moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Nd7: This was back when I played the Hanham Philidor move order. White gains an edge now with Bc4 after best play.
moves.4. c4: But this transposes into an Old Indian.
moves.4... Ngf6 5. Nc3 Be7 6. Bd3 O-O 7. Be3 R: This does not accomplish much. Better to develop and push the Q side pawns.
moves.13. Qe2 Nf6 14. h3 Be6: Purely to provoke d5, fixing the pawn structure.
moves.15. d5 Bd7 16. O-O-O cxd5: Now Black exchanges and hopes for an attack now that the King has decided its home.
moves.17. Nxd5 Nxd5 18. exd5 Rac8: White has undoubled the pawns, but Black hopes to get a strong attack in exchange.
moves.19. Kb1 e4: This advance is part of the plan, Black wants to play b5
moves.20. Bc2 a6 21. Rdf1 b5 22. Qf2 Qg6 23. c: Black now pressures the weak d pawn.
moves.28. h4 Qe6 29. Rhf1 a5: Black feels safe enough to counterattack on the King.
moves.30. Rd2 a4: Black wants to open the King up.
moves.31. g5 axb3 32. axb3 Bxb3 33. Bxb3 Qxb3+: Natural, but Whites King is wide open.
